description: The Linux in the Cloud series focuses on implementing the Linux operating system in a virtualized environment. Companies are relying less and less on dedicated hardware and are instead turning to shared hardware to optimize resource utilization and increase deployment flexibility. The hosts demonstrate virtualizing Linux using technologies like KVM and Docker as well as public cloud deployments using Amazon EC2 and Microsoft Azure.

Don can you tell us about

4

5

>> Well in this series we're gonna be
taking a look at what it's like to run

the Linux operating system on
top of various cloud services.

7
00:00:19.100 --> 00:00:21.970
A lot of people are virtualizing
environments now, either doing

8
00:00:21.970 --> 00:00:26.130
it in private clouds or public clouds and
clinics is a big part of that.

9
00:00:26.130 --> 00:00:31.490
For the most, it runs kind of the same
on an actual hardware verses on cloud or

10
00:00:31.490 --> 00:00:32.300
virtualized hardware.

11
00:00:32.300 --> 00:00:34.550
But in this series we're gonna
focus on those little differences,

12

the things that make it a little bit

13

The view it as a risk,
they don't want to deploy.

14
00:00:40.630 --> 00:00:43.910
We're gonna take a look at what's involved
in that and see what it takes to actually

15
00:00:43.910 --> 00:00:46.990
get this up and
running in a modern cloud infrastructure.

16
00:00:46.990 --> 00:00:49.550
>> Okay, and
who is this show targeted towards?

17
00:00:49.550 --> 00:00:51.968
>> Mainly this is gonna be targeted

18
00:00:51.968 --> 00:00:55.424
If you're responsible for supporting
a Linux infrastructure, and you've got

19
00:00:55.424 --> 00:00:59.000
on-premises equipment and now you're
starting to make that step into the cloud.

20
00:00:59.000 --> 00:01:02.040
Be it a private cloud with your
own virtualization servers or

21
00:01:02.040 --> 00:01:04.930
a public cloud with Amazon,
or Microsoft, or

22
00:01:04.930 --> 00:01:08.810
somebody like that,
it's a little tricky to make that jump.

23
00:01:08.810 --> 00:01:10.920
And so
this is really targeted towards you.

24
00:01:10.920 --> 00:01:13.740
>> So Don,
is there a certification involved in this?

25
00:01:13.740 --> 00:01:15.600
>> There's a number of cloud
certifications out there, but

26
00:01:15.600 --> 00:01:16.660
we're not gonna focus on that.

27
00:01:16.660 --> 00:01:19.440
We're just gonna try and
keep this as an introductory type thing,

28
00:01:19.440 --> 00:01:21.020
that's general audience.

29
00:01:21.020 --> 00:01:24.350
If you just wanna learn and be aware,
that's what this series is all about.

30
00:01:24.350 --> 00:01:28.044
So it's more focused on a technical
skill than it is a certification.

31
00:01:28.044 --> 00:01:30.039
>> And,
what topics are available in this show?

32
00:01:30.039 --> 00:01:33.520
>> Well, we're really covering
pretty much anything people ask for.

33
00:01:33.520 --> 00:01:37.770
But the main ones that we're gonna cover
here initially are gonna be Linux on KVM.

34
00:01:37.770 --> 00:01:39.540
KVM is tha Kernel Virtual Machine.

35
00:01:39.540 --> 00:01:43.810
It's the service that really Amazon
web services uses under the hood,

36
00:01:43.810 --> 00:01:44.840
you can run it privately.

37
00:01:44.840 --> 00:01:47.044
So we'll talk about it KVM host and

38
00:01:47.044 --> 00:01:50.315
then actually run Linux as
KVM guest on top of that.

39
00:01:50.315 --> 00:01:54.112
So creating a virtualized environment
entirely off of open source KVM.

40
00:01:54.112 --> 00:01:56.107
Then we'll take a look at Amazon EC2.

41
00:01:56.107 --> 00:01:59.993
So if you're using the elastic compute
cloud and you're deploying instances,

42
00:01:59.993 --> 00:02:03.949
VM's there, we'll see what it's like to
get Linux up and running inside of AWS.

43
00:02:03.949 --> 00:02:06.065
Then we're gonna move into
the Microsoft side of thing,

44
00:02:06.065 --> 00:02:07.220
I know it's funny to say that.

45
00:02:07.220 --> 00:02:08.840
Well we're gonna talk about
Microsoft on a Linux show.

46
00:02:08.840 --> 00:02:12.424
But it's really important because
Microsoft Azure is the number two player

47
00:02:12.424 --> 00:02:16.019
in cloud services right now, they have
created a massive infrastructure.

48
00:02:16.019 --> 00:02:18.611
So we'll see how to build up
our Linux virtual machines,

49
00:02:18.611 --> 00:02:20.075
get them thrown on top of Azure.

50
00:02:20.075 --> 00:02:23.898
And even though we're using a Microsoft
service we can still say in the Linux

51
00:02:23.898 --> 00:02:26.390
world and deploy things that we want.

52
00:02:26.390 --> 00:02:30.520
And then we're also going to really
bridge the gap and talk about Docker.

53
00:02:30.520 --> 00:02:34.520
Docker is a IT industry buzz word and
if you're a developer, you've

54
00:02:34.520 --> 00:02:38.080
got to learn that system administrators
are largely being neglected on this.

55
00:02:38.080 --> 00:02:42.460
And so I wanna take the time to show you
guys what Docker is, how it works, and

56
00:02:42.460 --> 00:02:45.570
we'll see how we can run Linux
inside of our Docker containers.

57
00:02:45.570 --> 00:02:49.340
As well as use Linux as our Docker host
to be able to power that environment and

58
00:02:49.340 --> 00:02:50.570
give a chance to see that.

59
00:02:50.570 --> 00:02:53.810
So these are all pretty typical
cloud type deployments, and

60
00:02:53.810 --> 00:02:56.570
we're gonna walk through them,
get comfortable with it, and

61
00:02:56.570 --> 00:03:00.710
make it where we can all recognize how
we can be using Linux as a ,loud OS.

62
00:03:00.710 --> 00:03:01.340
>> Thank you, Don.

63
00:03:01.340 --> 00:03:06.033
So Linux in the Cloud sounds like a show
you'd be interested in, and it should be,

64
00:03:06.033 --> 00:03:09.518

episodes.description: Don and Zach cover what is a KVM, how to know if your system supports KVM, how to find out if you have VMX or SVM, how to install KVM, rebooting after install, how we mange the server, and configuring KVM.
episodes.title: Linux as a KVM Host

episodes.description: Don and Zach discuss storage issues & if storage needs to be configured, KVM Storage Pools, default storage pool, Custom Storage Pools, basic setup of the server, and starting to create virtual machines.
episodes.title: Linux as a KVM Host Part 2

episodes.description: Don and Zach discuss what a KVM Guest is, what information we need before we create a VM, installation media, how KVM handles installation media, creating a VM, other VM options to configure, and beginning to install the Guest.
episodes.title: Linux as a KVM Guest

episodes.description: Don and Zach cover what EC2, what we need to know before we spin up our first instance, where we get the operating system for the instance, Amazon Machine Images (AMI), and how we launch the instance.
episodes.title: Creating an EC2 Instance

episodes.description: Don and Zach discuss if the installation is the same for different operating systems, adding additional user accounts, Amazon automatically updates and maintains servers only, not our OS, and other recommended maintenance of our servers.
episodes.title: Creating an EC2 Instance Part 2

episodes.description: Don and Zach cover one of the first things you configure on an instance, if are there any security options to worry about, security groups, and what we do if we don't want to expose the instance to the internet.
episodes.title: Configuring an EC2 Instance

episodes.description: Don an Zach discuss what Microsoft Azure is, what we need to know before we spin up our first Instance, Instance types, Linux VM pricing, where we get the operating system for the Instance, and deploying system image.
episodes.title: Creating an Azure VM

episodes.description: Don and Zach continue to create an Azure VM, what we need to do before launching the Instance, launching the Instance, logging into the Instance, initial access, and certificate or password.
episodes.title: Creating an Azure VM Part 2

episodes.description: Don and Zach cover one of the first things to customize on an Azure VM, how people can access our VM, if Azure has a solution to protect our VM's, creating a vault, defining a policy, and choosing Enable Backups.
episodes.title: Configuring an Azure VM

episodes.description: Don and Zach talk about what is 'Docker,' what we need to get Docker installed, the need to modify the configuration, creating containers, making the containers accessible locally & on the network, security settings, and name mapping in Docker.
episodes.title: Linux as a Docker Host

episodes.description: Don and Zach cover how we get started creating a container, using images to create build a container, running commands inside a container, and what happens when a container exits.
episodes.title: Linux as a Docker Container

episodes.description: Don and Zach continue looking at linux as a Docker container, saving changes, running a container in the background, if we normally run the containers interactively, how to clean up the containers we no longer need, stopping a container, and deleting a container.
episodes.title: Linux as a Docker Container Part 2
